As I write this, the final episode of Attack on Titan has just been released. An 85-minute finale to arguably one of the best shows of the last decade.
I’ll admit it — I didn’t like Attack on Titan on first watch.

I never really was much of a TV person, or an anime watcher, or a horror fan. I first heard of Attack on Titan in middle school, from friends who were reading the manga. I wasn’t really into the idea of “bladed Spidermen fighting cannibal giants”, and I didn’t really see where this story could go.
So I passed Attack on Titan. I only really started watching it when season four came out. I’d watched one of the trailers and I did a double take because I wasn’t sure it was the same show.
So, out of curiosity, I binged Attack on Titan in a week. Starting wtih “To You, 2,000 Years From Now”, and ending with “The Dawn Of Humanity”.
Then, out of pure incredulity, I binged it again.
And again.
And again.
To say that I was awestruck, or deeply moved, or anything that can fit within a sentence, is to do injustice to the way it asks its fundamental questions to us, the viewers.

I believe, firmly, that Isayama has created a modern-day epic that perfectly encapsulates the paradox and tragedy of human nature. The ending of AoT presents a perfect microcosm of the themes Isayama has woven through his work, as the Alliance assembles for a desperate final battle to save the remainder of humanity.
We see the confusion and strife of humanity. We see hate and love, fear and loyalty. We see humans become monsters, all while justifying their actions as correct.

Of particular note is Eren Yeager — the freedom-seeking hero-turned-villain whose choices shape the show from beginning to end. We see him seek freedom in the cruel world he was born into. We watch as, in the pursuit of freedom, he becomes the monster he once swore to destroy.
But what is true freedom? And does Eren — or anyone — ever find it?
For those who haven’t watched the final episode: spoilers ahead.

Attack on Titan draws deeply on Norse mythology. Superficially, we have the name “Ymir”, the founder and first Titan/giant in existence. The nine Titan shifters correspond to the nine realms of Yggdrasil, all born from Ymir’s flesh. In Ragnarok, the Norse end of days, the fire jotunn of Muspelheim lay waste to the world, just as the Rumbling crushes and scorches human civilization into the dust.
On a deeper level, Attack on Titan and Norse mythology also share the same narrative structure.

In Norse mythology, the world is a cycle. Jormungandr, the world serpent, circles the human realm of Midgard. Ragnarok is both destruction and rebirth, with a better world being born anew from the charred branches of Yggdrasil, the world tree. Baldur, the god of light, is reborn and leads this new world.

Likewise, in Attack on Titan, the Rumbling destroys the world as we know it. The survivors band together to build a new world. Armin, who had been reborn as a Titan shifter and fully understands the value of peace, heads the Alliance’s diplomatic delegation to Paradis.
In both Norse mythology and Attack on Titan, time is deterministic. The future can be observed through prophecy or Titan powers. Yet, it can’t be altered.
In Attack on Titan, this takes both a literal and figurative meaning. History is prewritten: the world’s destiny is set in stone, as Eren sees in his future memories.
Why? Because we see, time and time again, the same actions being taken, the same mistakes being made.

The Eldian Empire subjugated the world for two millennia with the Power of the Titans. Yet, when Eldia finally fell and Marley had a chance to do right, they chose to continue the cycle of war, using the Titans to conquer other countries and become another cruel superpower.

Reiner goes to Paradis fully believing in his mission of saving the world from devils, only to have his mind shatter when confronted with the truth. This story continues through his cousin, Gabi, who ends up making the same mistakes and same realizations.

Even when Ymir eliminates the Power of the Titans, when the ability of foresight vanishes from the world — even then, with seeming free will, war continues. Paradis is at peace for centuries, but war inevitably take its toll and leaves its cities as scarred, overgrown ruins.

Every side of every war in Attack on Titan attempts to justify their actions as “correct”. We start with the mindless Titans — the epitome of a good versus evil conflict — and a clear goal: to rid the world of Titans in order to save humanity.
As we uncover the existence of Titan shifters and find out the identities of the Armored, Female, and Colossal Titans, we see Reiner, Annie, and Bertholdt as the villains.
In the first half of season three, the royal government — specifically, the humans making up its corrupt structure — become the villains.
After the basement reveal, the villains become the entire outside world.

At the beginning of season four, we watch how from the perspective of the Marleyans, the people of Paradis are the true villains, “devils” even. The Survey Corps strikes Liberio in the same way the warriors broke the Wall in season one.

Back at Paradis, an increasingly corrupt military government is overthrown by the irredentist Yeagerists, who embrace Eldian exceptionalism and worship Eren as the messiah who will save them from the evils of the outside world. Here, the Yeagerists become the villains.
The original Survey Corps unites with their past foes to fight against a Paradis they no longer recognize, killing comrades for the goal of stopping the Rumbling.
In the end, Paradis falls into fascism, preparing for retaliation from the outside world for the Rumbling.
Who is right? Who is wrong? Attack on Titan argues such questions are meaningless. No one will always succeed the test of morality, because there isn’t even such a test to begin with.

Norse mythology, and likewise Attack on Titan, has no inherent morals — only motivations. Earth is born from the first murder, that of the giant Ymir by Odin, now chief of the Nordic pantheon. Countless lifeforms were born from Ymir’s dead body, desecrated by Odin for that goal.
Is Ymir’s murder “right” or “wrong”? In the end, such judgements say more about the judge’s personal values than the morality of the action itself.

As Eren Kruger said, there’s no singular right or wrong. It doesn’t matter whether Ymir — the first Titan shifter — was given her powers by God, the devil, or something in between. Regardless of morality, power will always be used.

There are no purely selfless struggles, like there’s no truly good or evil power. To serve one’s motivations is to serve oneself. We all have our own obsessive dreams that push us to do great and terrible things.
The conversation between Eren and Armin, and especially Eren’s breakdown, illustrates the paradox of struggle.

In the end, Eren remains that same emotional boy who protected his friends and fought for freedom. Deep down, he wants to live the long, happy life he wishes for his friends, but knows his actions have made this dream impossible.

Eren grew up enough to understand that the humans across the ocean were just like the Eldians within the Walls. Nonetheless, he chooses to ignore this newfound empathy in favour of wiping them out for his dream.

The conflict inside Eren is the conflict of these three core motivations. He wants to see the world in Armin’s book — the uninhabited, unexplored world waiting to be discovered. Yet, to reach this world, he must betray his friends and sacrifice his empathy for his world.
In other words, he must destroy what makes him human. He must fully become a monster.

Eren has the choice, and yet he has no choice. The Rumbling is written in stone, Eren is destined to destroy the outside world — and yet, critically, he chooses to do it because that’s what he most desires.

He tries to justify the atrocities he commits as being for the sake of his friends — but his friends living in peace are a consequence, rather than the main goal. It was always freedom — that hazy, vague notion of freedom beyond the Walls — that had driven him onward.

It’s telling that the same OST played in Eren’s confession — that same haunting trickle of piano notes — is the same that played during Reiner’s in Season 4 Part 1. Reiner rejects the excuses Eren offers him for attacking Wall Maria — being brainwashed, having no choice — and instead admits that his actions were out of his egoistic dream to become known as a hero.

We observe a quiet breakage, a tearing down of facade. Gone is warrior Reiner who killed Marco in cold blood, soldier Reiner who put his companions first. Gone is cold Eren who convinced himself of the necessity of the Rumbling to saving Paradis; soldier Eren who believed that in ridding the world of Titans, he would finally be free.
Here is Reiner, the bullied boy who wanted others to respect him at any cost. Here is Eren, the caged boy who murdered eighty percent of humanity for a glimpse of his unknown world beyond the Walls.

It’s the undoing of a character. What defines them, what drives them, dissolves into thin air. Faced with the approach of death, Eren and Reiner realize how meaningless their selfish choices have been.
Reiner is broken by Eren. Eren’s facade cracks through meeting Ramzi, and shatters during his conversation with Armin.

What separates Reiner and Eren are how they act after this breakage. Reiner chooses to continue fighting for his companions. He attempts to do what little good he can by saving others: first Falco and Gabi on Paradis, then the remainder of humanity from the Rumbling.
Eren, on the other hand. chooses to keep moving forward. He becomes an empty shell of a human being: a slave to freedom.

Eren, as a character, is designed to be without agency. He yearns to be free, despite knowing he will never be. He has all the power in the world, but he can’t stop himself from repeating the same mistakes as his predecessors.
Eren is never special: he is just an idiot who got too much power.
As Kenny Ackermann notes in his dying moments, everyone has to be drunk on something to keep moving onward. To have purpose means to serve oneself. To live with a dream is to be inherently selfish.
So what do we make of this all?
What purpose does it all serve to struggle?
Should we become like Zeke, looking forward to the end of days and the disappearance of fear?
Is life meaningless, beyond the desperate fight to survive?
Isayama answers in the form of the Survey Corps. They are free: the wings of humanity, flying high above the ground, burning bright for the sake of others.
The Survey Corps is the very embodiment of freedom, of beauty, of the best of humanity.
To dedicate your heart, as Levi tells Erwin, is to give up on your dreams and to be willing to die, so that others have the freedom to experience the ephemeral beauty of life.
So Erwin gives up on his selfish dream — finding out what’s beyond the Walls — and sacrifices himself for the sake of defeating the Beast Titan and saving the people of the Walls — his people.

To some extent, we are all Zeke Yeager. Zeke, who thought the only escape from suffering was to never be born. Who only realized at the end how much meaning the simple pleasure of playing catch with Dr. Ksaver brought into his life.
We are all Eren, who sought freedom so desperately he never stopped to enjoy the simple things in front of him: the seashell, for instance, which Armin hands him during their final conversation.
We are all the lost characters of Attack on Titan, so obsessed with the greater world that we forget to find meaning in that which is right in front of us.
The characters who make this discovery are those who are truly free.
Jean abandons his dream of a “cushy life in the Interior” in order to honour his promise to Marco and to his companions in the Survey Corps.
Zeke chooses to help stop the Rumbling because he discovers, through Armin, the value of small yet precious things.
Gabi, the child soldier who believed her purpose was to win, finally accepts a simple life with Falco at her side, rebuilding the world.
Mikasa kills Eren, her beloved, both to end his suffering and to save all the other beloved people in the world.
And Ymir, after seeing what true love looks like, finally breaks free of King Fritz and ends the Titan curse.
Grand things, like war, are everlasting and ugly. It’s the fleeting things — peace, love, friendship — which are truly beautiful, precisely because they don’t last.

In this sense, Attack on Titan espouses spiritual freedom akin to Buddhist enlightenment. Isayama teaches us to have empathy for everyone around us. To pierce through the fog of war and understand the cyclic nature of violence. To find meaning in the rare glimpses of beauty and goodness that shine through all the strife and suffering of the world.
Attack on Titan reminds us to latch on to these moments for whatever time we have. Because only then, will we transcend the cycle of conflict.
Only then, will we be truly free.
Casual writer. Sushi lover. Polyglot — ZH, EN, FR, ES, DE, some AR. Quality > Quantity. Views are mine.

Eren Yeager is one of the most complex, fascinating, and talked-about characters in modern anime. As the central figure of Attack on Titan (AoT), his journey captivates audiences with its exploration of morality, vengeance, freedom, and destiny. Few protagonists in anime have undergone as much transformation—both literally and figuratively—as Eren Yeager. His decisions reverberate throughout the narrative, setting the stage for a larger commentary on human nature and the cost of survival.

Whether you’re a die-hard Attack on Titan fan or just dipping your toes into its incredible story, Eren Yeager’s arc is worth diving into. Let’s explore his development, ideologies, powers, and the elements that make him an unforgettable character in the world of anime.

At the heart of Attack on Titan is Eren Yeager, a young boy living behind the walls of a city that shields humanity from Titans—gigantic man-eating creatures. From the very beginning, Eren’s goals are crystal clear: he craves freedom, despises oppression, and is driven by a burning desire to wipe out Titans.

Eren is introduced as a spirited teenager whose world collapses when Titans invade his home, Wall Maria. Watching his mother being devoured by a Titan spurs Eren’s thirst for vengeance and sets him on the path to becoming a member of the elite Survey Corps, the group tasked with fighting Titans and uncovering their secrets.

His early characterization resonates with viewers. He’s passionate, idealistic, and somewhat impulsive. But as the series unfolds, Eren grows into a character far more complex than your average anime protagonist.
One of the defining aspects of Eren Yeager’s character is his evolution. He begins as a heroic figure, dedicated to protecting humanity. Yet, as the series progresses, he takes a darker turn.

Eren’s transformation can be traced to the revelation of the Titans’ origins and the history of the world beyond the walls. His quest for freedom shifts from fighting external threats to questioning humanity itself. He begins to see himself as a savior, but his methods become increasingly ruthless. This moral ambiguity is what makes Eren Yeager such an enthralling figure—he forces audiences to grapple with difficult questions about justice, revenge, and sacrifice.

Consider this: Is Eren still a hero when he uses the power of the Founding Titan to unleash the Rumbling? His decision to flatten entire nations to secure the future of Paradis Island polarizes viewers. On one hand, he fulfills his promise to protect his homeland. On the other hand, the devastation he causes raises ethical questions about the cost of his actions.

Eren’s power as a Titan Shifter is central to his character. Unlike regular humans, Eren can transform into a Titan at will, granting him immense physical strength and regenerative abilities. Over the course of the series, Eren gains control over multiple Titan forms:

These abilities make Eren a formidable figure, but they also come with immense responsibility. As the story progresses, his mastery of these powers reflects his inner transformation—from a boy wanting to destroy Titans to a man challenging the world’s power structures.

Eren Yeager’s actions are motivated by a deep-rooted belief in freedom. His mantra, “If you don’t fight, you can’t win,” encapsulates his philosophy. This relentless pursuit of liberation drives many of his decisions.

However, Eren’s concept of freedom is nuanced. It evolves from a personal dream of exploring the world beyond the walls to a collective goal of securing a future for his people. In doing so, Eren wrestles with questions about the price of freedom. Is it right to sacrifice others for one’s ideals? How do you reconcile personal dreams with the larger good?
Eren’s relationships with other characters form the emotional backbone of Attack on Titan. Here are the key dynamics that shape his journey:

Eren’s quest for freedom is a recurring theme in Attack on Titan. His journey examines what it means to be free, the sacrifices it demands, and whether true freedom is even attainable in a flawed world.

Eren’s transformation challenges traditional notions of good and evil. Is he a villain for causing destruction or a savior acting in the best interest of his people? The series invites viewers to question the morality of Eren’s choices.
As a Titan Shifter with world-altering abilities, Eren grapples with the immense weight of responsibility. His decisions carry consequences not only for himself but for all of humanity.
Eren’s determination to rise above loss and trauma serves as an inspiring reminder of the importance of perseverance.
Eren’s actions highlight the duality of humanity—capable of both great love and destruction.
Through Eren’s journey, Attack on Titan pushes us to reconsider black-and-white definitions of right and wrong.

Eren Yeager’s character is a masterclass in storytelling. From his initial innocence to his ultimate transformation into a morally complex figure, Eren’s journey mirrors the grand questions of humanity: What does it mean to be free? What are we willing to sacrifice for our ideals? Through triumphs and tragedies, Eren Yeager reminds us that the pursuit of freedom is never straightforward—it’s as messy and multifaceted as human nature itself.
Eren is driven by a deep desire for freedom stemming from personal trauma and a longing to explore the world beyond the walls.
Eren’s transformation into an antihero occurs as he adopts ruthless methods to achieve his goal of protecting Paradis Island, blurring the line between hero and villain.
Eren can transform into the Attack Titan, Founding Titan, and War Hammer Titan, each offering unique abilities crucial to the story.
Eren and Mikasa share a deep bond rooted in mutual protection and care, though their dynamic evolves as Eren grows more distant in later arcs.
The Rumbling showcases Eren’s ultimate plan to secure freedom for Paradis, but it also illustrates the devastating cost of his actions.
Eren’s journey, marked by transformation, moral ambiguity, and philosophical questions about freedom, makes him one of the most multi-dimensional characters in anime history.
